description: From Middle English capston; equivalent to cap +‎ stone.

entries.meaning: Any of the stones making up the top layer of a wall; a coping stone.
(figurative) A crowning achievement, culmination or finishing touch.
examples: “You see, I’ve never had a girl friend,” I added, by way of topping the obelisk of silliness with the capstone of fatuity.

verbs.description: capstone (third-person singular simple present capstones, present participle capstoning, simple past and past participle capstoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To complete as a crowning achievement; to top off.
examples: Capstoning a decade's worth of linked short stories, The Quiet War (2008) was a vivid and tense novel about a solar system sliding into conflict.

entries.meaning: (transitive, US, military, informal) To train in the Capstone Military Leadership Program.
examples: “Capstoned” units are now able to train and plan in peacetime with the command with which they will fight in wartime.
